title: Fair Play
plotSummary: A group of young men (Itwara Anthony, Kafuruka Peter, Collin Asiimwe and Godfrey K.) in rural Ugandan town decide to be more involved in the political process.
overview: A group of young men (Itwara Anthony, Kafuruka Peter, Collin Asiimwe and Godfrey K.) in rural Ugandan town decide to be more involved in the political process after their football pitch has been allocated to a private investor with the help of their local councillor. They take advantage of the upcoming by-election to find a candidate to save their football pitch. The club captain, Kato (Peter Kafuruka) contests as a compromise candidate of the Citizens Empowerment Party (CEP). However, Kato’s conservative parents belong to different parties and are not amused; they do not even support him. Can Kato, a barber and teacher, manage the tough game of politics?

title: Windows of Hope
plotSummary: When the thin line between love and hate gets blurred for Alinda (Nyakake Harriet) and Nyanzi (Akwehaire Steven), their child Barugahara (Itwara Anthony) feels the pain.
overview: When the thin line between love and hate gets blurred for Alinda (Nyakake Harriet) and Nyanzi (Akwehaire Steven), their child Barugahara (Itwara Anthony) feels the pain. He is rejected, unloved, uncared for and robbed of his inheritance. Barugahara courageously faces life, only keeping hope alive…How does he consider his relatives when he becomes very successful?

title: Fate
plotSummary: Kate Komuntale (Nantongo Justine), a high-flying Kampala Corporate Executive in her thirties, has everything except a family: a husband and a child.
overview: Kate Komuntale (Nantongo Justine), a high-flying Kampala Corporate Executive in her thirties, has everything except a family: a husband and a child. Society builds pressure on her to marry so as to complete her success. In that quagmire, Ken Bagonza (Allie Mutaka), a smooth-talking intelligence officer, breezes into the scene and easily sweeps Kate off her feet and up to the altar. But Ken has a sinister agenda… Bliss turns to hell. Kate has to dig deeper into her inner reservoir of strength to survive Ken’s crazy womanising, wild temper and, above all, singly parent ‘sensitive’ Ivan … Is it fate or choice?

title: Tuko Pamoja(We are one)
plotSummary: Tuko Pamoja explores the geopolitical and geolinguistics of the 1870-1900 Great Lakes nations (kingdoms and chiefdoms) that became colonial Uganda.
overview: Tuko Pamoja explores the geopolitical and geolinguistics of the 1870-1920 Great Lakes nations (kingdoms and chiefdoms) that became colonial Uganda. The documentary primarily constructs and deconstructs the history of colonial confrontation by interviewing historians, various cultural leaders, and opinion leaders in Uganda. Information about Uganda’s recent past is from interviews with historians (academic and non-academic), opinion leaders, senior citizens and youths from various communities. Guided by the oral tradition culture, the filmmaker (Cindy Magara) goes into the community to seek an in-depth understanding of the construction of cultural identity/ethnicity and how they relate or fit in the larger Uganda (and, by extension East Africa) that is seen to have closely linked, yet diverse peoples.

episodes.plotSummary: See the history of the Kitara Empire, which morphed into Bunyoro-Kitara, one of the largest empires in East and Central Africa. Explore the detailed story of Omukama (king) John Cwa II Kabaleega, who was a paramount king of East Africa’s kingdoms and chiefdoms. Kabaleega's nation encapsulates the thesis of the Tuko Pamoja (We are one) series.

Explore the systematic growth of an embryonic kingdom with strong links with Bunyoro and Bugisu that grew from a mere three counties to a nation. How did embattled Mwanga’s Buganda manage to remain a nation within a nation in the post-colonial Uganda, yet it was a springboard of British colonialism?
Journey to the picturesque source of the Nile where we explore the birth of a nation that was, for a long time, a pawn of Bunyoro and Buganda kingdoms. It was and is still a gateway into Uganda.

episodes.episodeTitle: Ankole:Kaaro-Karungi(Nkore), Buhweju, Buzimba and Mpororo States
episodes.plotSummary: Ankole: Nkore, Buhweju, Buzimba and Mpororo States). Originallly woven around Ankore((Kaaro-Karungi—the beautiful village) is a tale of a people linked to Bunyoro and Rwanda. Ankole’s misnomer of Nkore and it exemplifies the colonial concoction of a kingdom, whose repercussions reverberate in today’s Ankore, a ghost kingdom.

episodes.episodeTitle: The ‘Ango’ peoples: Lango, Karamojong and Iteso
episodes.plotSummary: The ‘Ango’ peoples: Lango, Karamojong and Itesots. The self-proclaimed Jews’ narratives is a tapestry of the Ateker people in East Africa and, more so, the role played by the Langi in defending pre-colonial Uganda. The Langi, who are Ateker by DNA and Luo by language, stand out as significant in the history of Uganda since they were protecting Uganda’s last independent kings: Omukama Kabaleega and Kabaka Mwanga in Kangai.

episodes.episodeTitle: Eastern Uganda: Bagisu & Babukusu; Samia and Bagwe (The Luhyas)
episodes.plotSummary: This segment underscores the hybridity that results from two ethnic groups (the Nilotics and the Bantus); and the fact that the Berlin-drawn borders divided people into different countries, but the ordinary people have disregarded the artificial borders.

Tooro is like a siamese twin of Bunyoro Kitara, both Banyoro and Batooroare are closely linked to their ancestors—the Luos—whose names they adorn as praise names (Amooti, Abwooli, Akiiki, Abbala, etc.).

Information about Uganda’s recent past is from interviews with historians (academic and non-academic), opinion leaders, senior citizens and youths from various communities. Guided by the oral tradition culture, the filmmaker (Cindy Magara) goes into the community to seek an in-depth understanding of the construction of cultural identity/ethnicity and how they relate or fit in the larger Uganda (and, by extension East Africa) that is seen to have closely linked yet diverse peoples.

episodes.plotSummary: See the history of the Kitara Empire, one of the largest empires in East and Central Africa. The detailed story of Omukama (king) John Cwa II Kabaleega, who was a paramount king of East Africa’s kingdoms and chiefdoms, encapsulates the thesis of the Tuko Pamoja (We are one) series.

See the systematic growth of an embryonic kingdom with strong links with Bunyoro and Bugisu that grew from a mere three counties to a nation. How did embattled Mwanga’s Buganda manage to remain a nation within a nation in the post-colonial Uganda, yet it was a springboard of British colonialism?

Spread all over Uganda and the Great Lakes Region, the Luo’s civilisation is felt in all parts of this world because they were and still are the rulers of the major Kingdoms in the region, from whose lineage we get great world leaders: Raila Odinga, Barack Obama

_id.episodeTitle: Ankole:Kaaro-Karungi(Nkore), Buhweju, Buzimba and Mpororo States
_id.plotSummary: Ankole brings on-screen people linked to Bunyoro and Rwanda. Because Ankole’s misnomer exemplifies the colonial concoction of a kingdom,  the colonial repercussions reverberate in today’s Ankore (there is a shell of a kingdom).

episodes.plotSummary: The Banyakigezi (people of Kigezi) higlights the impact of artificial borders that stopped the natural relationship of East Africans—Ugandans and Rwandans, Tanzanians, and Congolese are one. Through the tales of East Africa’s Queen Muhumuza, Chief Katuregye and Makobore, we learn that this is one part of Uganda that was not directly colonised by the imperialists.

_id.episodeTitle: Eastern Uganda: Bagisu & Babukusu; Samia and Bagwe (The Luhyas)
_id.plotSummary: This segment underscores the hybridity that results from two ethnic groups (the Nilotics and the Bantus) and the fact that the Berlin-drawn borders divided people into different countries, but the ordinary people have disregarded the artificial borders.

episodes.episodeTitle: Lado Enclave: West Nilers: (Lugbara, Aringa, Madi and Kakwa)
episodes.plotSummary: This is a tall tale of the descendants of black Egyptians. These cousins of Luos and, mostly heavily intermarried among the Banyoro, have a village called Worokomba (Muzungu ends here), but their chief resister, Achief Aliku, is not among the mainstream resisters of foreign aggression. Tuko Pamoja weaves a story of people, who were tossed from DRC to Uganda, yet are still divided by the artificial border from their kins in DRC and Sudan.

_id.plotSummary: Spread all over Uganda and the Great Lakes Region, the Luo’s civilisation is felt in all parts of this world because they were and still are the rulers of the major Kingdoms in the region.

episodes.plotSummary: “To be or not to be…” comes alive in the tales of chiefdoms that have recently broken away from Buganda at a time when nations are aspiring to federate into bigger blocks. The answer is in history: even the Bugandas and Bunyoros (greatest kingdoms in Uganda) were formed at a certain time.

_id.episodeTitle: Lado Enclave: West Nilers: (Lugbara, Aringa, Madi and Kakwa)
_id.plotSummary: These cousins of Luos and, mostly heavily intermarried among the Banyoro, have a village called Worokomba (Muzungu ends here), but their chief resister, Achief Aliku, is not among the mainstream resisters of foreign aggression. Tuko Pamoja weaves a story of people who were tossed from DRC to Uganda, yet are still divided by the artificial border from their kins in DRC and Sudan.

episodes.episodeTitle: Kingdoms of the Mountains of Moon: Bakonzo, Bamba and Basongora
episodes.plotSummary: Be witness to the continued injustice caused by the Berlin conference, as almost everyone in the Rwenzori region has a relative in Congo.

_id.episodeTitle: Kingdoms of the Mountains of Moon (The Rwenzori (Rwenzururu/ Rwenjura) peoples
_id.plotSummary: Bakonjo, Bamba and Basongora. Be witness to the continued injustice caused by the Berlin conference, as almost everyone in the Rwenzori region has a relative in Congo.

episodes.episodeTitle: Uganda: The Making of a Nation
episodes.plotSummary: Explore how the diverse, yet interconnected peoples of contemporary Uganda handle the post-colonial dispensation after being clamped together into a country called Uganda. How are they fostering national unity after five decades of independence?

episodes.episodeTitle: Uganda: The Making of a Nation
episodes.plotSummary: Explore how the diverse yet interconnected peoples of contemporary Uganda handle the post-colonial dispensation after being clamped together into a country called Uganda. How are they fostering national unity after five decades of independence?
